Yeah, the yamagane tsuba is massive. I will have to measure it when I get a
chance. Your tsuba does look early to me. I think Jim would be the best
judge of that, however,

Gordon
  -----Original Message-----
  From: Richard George [mailto:rkg@...]
  Sent: Saturday, May 24, 2003 1:54 PM
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] polearm tsuba question


  Gordon ,

  the piece is confusing - the nakago ana definitely looks like a polearm
  blade went through it, and it does seem
  much bigger than most of the naginata tsuba I've seen so I'd believe it
  was used on a nagamaki - the question
  I can't resolve is "when" - there is some strange stuff about it - like
  the carving on the surface is the same theme
  on both sides, but reversed - what's on the top side on one side is on
  the bottom side on the other...  and yeah,
  its definitely covered with lacquer - perhaps several coats of it - but
  then again,  the fukurin is definitely silver,
  but maybe its thin enough that they stuck it on later (say in the
  shin-shinto era when people started doing
  stuff with these again) perhaps?

  BTW, what are the approximate dimensions on that yamagahane nagamaki
  tsuba?  does the beast weigh a
  lot?

  thx,

  rkg
  (Richard George)

  >Hi Richard,
  >
  >Have not seen anything like that on a nagamaki or naginata. The tsuba on
the
  >Uesugi Kenshin pieces are yamagane and kiku shaped sukashi pieces. My
  >nagamaki has a rounded-square disk in yamagane -- absolutely plain.
  >
  >Gordon
  >  -----Original Message-----
  >  From: Richard George [mailto:rkg@...]
  >  Sent: Friday, May 23, 2003 1:21 PM
  >  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  >  Subject: [nihontostudy] polearm tsuba question
  >
  >
  >  hey guys,
  >
  >  Are there any other polearm lovers out there - check out this tsuba -
it
  >  supposedly came off a nagamaki:
  >
  >  http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/misc/front_small.JPG
  >  http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/misc/front_small.JPG
  >  http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/misc/edge_small.JPG
  >  (there are a few other closeups in the same directory, but I didn't
  >  quite get a couple of 'em in focus - sorry about
  >  presenting this upside down, but I really busy last night and didn't
get
  >  a chance to rotate the photos...).
  >
  >  The piece is 2.885" by 2.73" by.21" thick at the rim and ~.175 in the
  >  center.  The rim appears to be
  >  silver, and the sukashi pieces appear to be filled with lead.
  >
  >  The piece appears to be pretty old (Jim pointed out that it looked like
  >  there were a couple of layers of lacquer
  >  on it), and the lead makes it really heavy for a tsuba of this size.
  >
  >  So, has anybody seen something like this on a "real" naginata/nagamaki
  >  koshirae?  any attempts at kantei, observations,
  >  etc., would be greatly appreciated.
  >
  >  thanks,
  >
  >  rkg
  >  (Richard George)
